verses.text: Now Adam knew Eve his wife, and she conceived and bore Cain, saying, 'I have gotten a man with the help of the Lord.'
verses.comment: The phrase 'knew' refers to intimate marital union. Eve recognizes God’s active role in the birth of her child, a theme pointing toward the divine gift of human life.

verses.text: And again, she bore his brother Abel. Now Abel was a keeper of sheep, and Cain was a worker of the ground.
verses.comment: The mention of occupation foreshadows later biblical imagery: Abel as a shepherd prefigures Christ, the Good Shepherd (John 10:11).

verses.text: In the course of time Cain brought to the Lord an offering of the fruit of the ground.
verses.comment: Here we see the earliest form of worship through offerings. The concept of first fruits and sacrifice forms the basis for later liturgical actions.

verses.text: And Abel also brought an offering—of the firstborn of his flock and of their fat portions. The Lord looked with favor on Abel and his offering,
verses.comment: Abel’s offering, which involved the best and firstborn, aligns with the later principle of offering our very best to God. This also foreshadows sacrificial themes, culminating in Christ as the Lamb of God (John 1:29).

verses.text: but for Cain and his offering he had no regard. So Cain was very angry, and his face fell.
verses.comment: God’s response highlights the importance of the heart behind worship. The contrast points toward true interior devotion beyond mere ritual.

verses.text: The Lord said to Cain, 'Why are you angry? And why has your face fallen?'
verses.comment: God initiates dialogue, offering Cain a chance for self-examination and repentance—a pattern that recurs throughout Scripture.

verses.text: 'If you do well, will you not be accepted? But if you do not do well, sin is crouching at the door. Its desire is for you, but you must rule over it.'
verses.comment: The warning marks the human struggle with sin but also a call to moral responsibility. The language of 'ruling over' sin anticipates themes of spiritual discipline and grace.

verses.text: Cain spoke to Abel his brother. And when they were in the field, Cain rose up against his brother Abel and killed him.
verses.comment: The first murder is not just a historical fact but a sign of separation caused by sin. Abel’s death prefigures innocent suffering in Scripture and is a type of Christ’s sacrificial death.

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Cain, 'Where is Abel your brother?' He said, 'I do not know; am I my brother’s keeper?'
verses.comment: Cain’s reply reflects moral evasion and denial of responsibility. The question 'Am I my brother’s keeper?' underpins later teaching on charity and love of neighbor.

verses.text: And the Lord said, 'What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood cries out to me from the ground.'
verses.comment: This verse is foundational for doctrines regarding the sanctity of life. Abel’s blood crying out prefigures the greater blood that speaks mercy—Christ (Heb. 12:24).

verses.text: And now you are cursed from the ground, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother’s blood from your hand.
verses.comment: The curse deepens. Unlike Adam, who was cursed for disobedience, Cain is cursed directly for violence, showing the escalating effects of sin.

verses.text: When you work the ground, it shall no longer yield its strength to you. You shall be a fugitive and a wanderer on the earth.
verses.comment: The consequences of sin are both spiritual and physical. The wandering motif prefigures themes of exile and restoration later in Scripture.

verses.text: Cain said to the Lord, 'My punishment is greater than I can bear.'
verses.comment: Cain’s lament reveals the weight of sin and prompts reflection on the need for mercy and redemption, themes fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: 'Behold, you have driven me this day away from the ground, and from your face I shall be hidden. I shall be a fugitive and a wanderer on the earth, and whoever finds me will kill me.'
verses.comment: Cain fears alienation not only from the land but from God’s presence. The notion of being ‘hidden from God’s face’ is significant for spiritual consequences of sin.

verses.text: Then the Lord said to him, 'Not so! If anyone kills Cain, vengeance shall be taken on him sevenfold.' And the Lord put a mark on Cain, lest any who found him should kill him.
verses.comment: Despite Cain’s sin, God shows mercy and protection, establishing the principle of measured justice and mercy (a precursor to spiritual forgiveness and reconciliation).

verses.text: So Cain went out from the presence of the Lord and settled in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
verses.comment: Departure from God’s presence signifies spiritual exile. The eastward movement is associated with distancing from paradise, a motif recurring throughout biblical history.

verses.text: Cain knew his wife, and she conceived and bore Enoch. Cain was building a city, and he named the city after his son Enoch.
verses.comment: The act of building a city marks the beginning of human civilization, though in the context of Cain’s alienation, this parallels later themes of cities but also human estrangement from God.

verses.text: To Enoch was born Irad; and Irad fathered Mehujael, and Mehujael fathered Methushael, and Methushael fathered Lamech.
verses.comment: These genealogies show the continuation of humanity despite sin, setting up the contrast between righteous and unrighteous lines.

verses.text: And Lamech took two wives: the name of one was Adah, and the name of the other Zillah.
verses.comment: Lamech’s polygamy contrasts with the established ideal of monogamous union earlier in Genesis, showing departure from divine intention.

verses.text: Adah bore Jabal; he was the father of those who dwell in tents and have livestock.
verses.comment: Jabal’s line is credited with shepherding and nomadic living, which becomes a significant motif in salvation history (see Abraham, Moses, David).

verses.text: His brother’s name was Jubal; he was the father of all those who play the lyre and pipe.
verses.comment: The mention of music points ahead to its important role in worship and liturgy throughout biblical tradition.

verses.text: Zillah bore Tubal-cain; he was the forger of all instruments of bronze and iron. The sister of Tubal-cain was Naamah.
verses.comment: Tubal-cain’s skills in metalwork foreshadow later advances in civilization and even the use of materials for sacred purposes.

verses.text: Lamech said to his wives, 'Adah and Zillah, hear my voice; you wives of Lamech, listen to what I say: I have killed a man for wounding me, a young man for striking me.'
verses.comment: Lamech boasts of violence, intensifying the legacy of Cain. This narrative arc contrasts with aspirations for peace and reconciliation found later in scripture.

verses.text: 'If Cain is avenged sevenfold, then Lamech seventy-sevenfold.'
verses.comment: Lamech’s escalation is contrasted by Christ’s call to forgive ‘seventy times seven’ (Matt. 18:22), exemplifying reversal and fulfillment in the Gospel.

verses.text: And Adam knew his wife again, and she bore a son and named him Seth, for she said, 'God has appointed for me another offspring instead of Abel, for Cain killed him.'
verses.comment: The birth of Seth marks renewal and hope after tragedy. Seth’s line is preserved, ultimately leading to the fulfillment of God’s plan in salvation history.

verses.text: To Seth also a son was born, and he called his name Enosh. At that time people began to call upon the name of the Lord.
verses.comment: The beginning of public worship here anticipates both individual and communal prayer traditions, later developed in the history of the church, which carries this calling forward through centuries of liturgy and prayer.
